Project Number: 45295 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
 
Addressing Disaster Risk through Improved Indicators 
and Land Use Management  
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

GLOSSARY 
 
Climate change  –  Adjustment in natural or human systems in response to actual or 
adaptation  expected  climatic  stimuli  or  their  effects  that moderates  harm  or 
exploits beneficial opportunities.  
Disaster  –  A serious disruption to the functioning of a community or a society, 
  causing widespread human, economic, or environmental losses that 
exceed the ability of the affected community or society to cope using 
its own resources. 
Disaster risk  –  The  systematic  process  of  using  administrative  decisions, 
management  organizations,  operational  skills,  and  capacities  to  implement  a 
  society’s policies, strategies, and coping capacities to lessen the 
  impacts of natural hazards and related disasters. 
Disaster risk  –  A series of interconnected actions to minimize disaster vulnerability 
reduction  by avoiding (prevention) or limiting (mitigation and preparedness) the 
adverse effects of hazards within the broad context of sustainable 
development.

Exposure  –  The sum total of human life, economic activities, and assets at risk of 
loss if a hazard leads to a disaster. Or, in the context of an insurance 
contract, the total of insured assets (or the sum insured) at risk of 
loss resulting from the occurrence of the event insured against at 
any one time. 
Hazard  –  A  potentially  damaging  physical  event,  phenomenon,  or  human 
  activity that may cause loss of life, injury, property damage, social 
and economic disruption, or environmental degradation. 
Integrated disaster  –  As used in this report, integrated disaster risk management refers to 
risk  systematic  activities  that  aim  to  avoid,  lessen,  or  transfer  the 
management  potential  adverse  effects  of  all  hazards,  specifically  through  the 
  integration of climate change adaptation, disaster risk finance, and 
disaster risk reduction measures.  
Relief or  –  The terms are used interchangeably in the literature to mean the 
response  provision of assistance or intervention during or immediately after a 
disaster to meet the life preservation and basic subsistence needs of 
those affected. Duration can be immediate, short-term, or extended. 
Risk assessment  –  A  methodology  to  determine  the  nature  and  extent  of  risk  by 
analyzing potential hazards and evaluating conditions of vulnerability 
that pose a potential threat or harm to people, property, livelihoods, 
and the environment on which they depend. 
Vulnerability  –  Conditions  determined  by  physical,  social,  economic,  and 
environmental  factors  that  increase  community  susceptibility  to 
hazard impact.

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area. 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Development  gains  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  are  increasingly  under  threat  from  the 
impacts of disasters due to natural hazards and climate change. With the economic costs of 
disasters averaging $53.8 billion a year in Asia and the Pacific between 2005 and 2010,1 the 
combined development assistance contributions of all the region’s development partners does 
not keep pace with the economic and social costs of disasters in Asia and the Pacific. This 
assistance amounted to $32 billion for the developing member countries (DMCs) of the Asian 
Development bank (ADB) in 2009.2 Ultimately, this means that progress toward the Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) and other development targets is being undermined by disaster 
damage and losses that adversely affect development investments. 
 
2.  To reverse this trend, greater attention is needed to address disaster risk management 
(DRM) in the context of development planning and practice. Since development projects by 
necessity have a local presence and footprint, a key entry point for this integration is the land 
use management process, which is one of the principle components of local development 
planning. While there are gaps and deficiencies in the practice of land use planning in many 
parts of Asia and the Pacific, a focus on improving practice and making land use management 
more risk sensitive will enable stronger outcomes for protecting development investments. 
 
3.  Through this technical assistance (TA) project, ADB will support a series of focused 
research and development activities to review the obstacles that have arisen in the past in 
effectively addressing DRM in the context of land use planning and enforcement, the solutions 
that are being developed to overcome these obstacles, and the best ways to share these good 
practices with a wide set of development practitioners within DMCs.3 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
4.  ADB was the first multilateral development bank to have a dedicated disaster policy4; 
ADB’s long commitment to DRM is reinforced in Strategy 2020, with DRM, climate change 
adaptation (CCA), and risk financing identified as core areas of operations.5 ADB promotes an 
integrated disaster risk management effort based on (i) disaster risk reduction (DRR), (ii) CCA, 
and (iii) disaster risk financing (DRF). Between 1987 and May 2011, ADB contributed $12.55 
billion to DRM activities through 522 projects. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  High levels of urbanization and poverty and low levels of effective risk governance are 
compounding  disaster  exposure  and  vulnerability  for  populations  throughout  Asia  and  the 
Pacific. Population settlements have often been located in areas of high disaster risk because of 
their geographic amenities—such as easy communication and transport along rivers and coasts 
and locations along coastal mountains that are picturesque and offer better defense; these 
amenities also, however, bring significant exposure to disaster hazards. These same rivers and 
coasts are often at high risk for flooding, and coastal mountains or bays are often situated along 
ridgelines or trench lines linked to earthquakes faults.

6.  This vulnerability is exacerbated by faulty systems of land management in which lands, 
which should have been left as floodplains, fault easements, or forests, are deemed habitable or 
used for informal settlement due to a lack of effective land access policies. As more people 
migrate into existing settlements that typically have weak regulatory and planning regimes, the 
carrying capacities of both natural resource and infrastructure systems are increasingly strained, 
and the poorest and most vulnerable often find themselves living on risk-prone marginal land. 
Weak compliance with and enforcement of building regulations increase the vulnerability of 
urban housing and infrastructure to hazard events. In these situations, individual and household 
incentives for investing in risk reduction are diminished, leading to accumulations of disaster 
vulnerability, damage, and loss, which lead to further poverty in a negative spiral. Climate 
change is predicted to increase these negative impacts through both the increased frequency 
and severity of certain types of disaster events and the impacts on livelihoods that may reduce 
coping capacities. 
 
7.  The trend of urban risk accumulation can be reversed if risk-sensitive policies and 
practices are incorporated into urban development. Land use planning and zoning are standard 
tools for managing urban development, are used to varying extents throughout most countries in 
Asia  and  the  Pacific,  and  can  be  readily  modified  to  include  risk  management  elements. 
However, in most instances, existing land use plans are not properly implemented or enforced 
with regard to protecting against disaster risk and do not incorporate mechanisms for DRR or 
CCA. In essence, the land use planning process and its regulatory environment are risk-blind.  
 
8.  The knowledge exists to achieve risk-resilient development, and there is an increasing 
awareness  among  development  professionals  of  the  negative  consequences  of  disaster 
hazards, including those related to climate change. However, this knowledge has not found its 
way into day-to-day practice. The main reason is that disaster risk management and adaptation 
are still often managed separately from urban development planning. To bridge this gap, better 
tools and shared learning are needed that highlight how to take advantage of opportunities for 
integrating risk reduction into urban development processes and systems and for using an all-
hazards approach that captures the synergies between CCA and DRR so that investments in 
these areas offer two-pronged protection. These tools and learning also need to be carefully 
matched to the specific needs and context of the planners and development professionals, and 
incorporated into disaster risk management practices. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be strengthened access to tools and guidance on risk-sensitive 
land use planning and development leading to reduced urban disaster risk in DMCs. The 
outcome will be enhanced knowledge of risk-sensitive land use planning and development 
among participating DMCs. 
  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The proposed TA will support an interactive process with a selected set of cities to 
review innovative urban risk reduction practice in those cities and elsewhere, and to develop 
guidance materials to more effectively address risk reduction and adaptation in the design, 
implementation, and management of urban development projects. The target audience for these 
guidance materials will be city planners and managers within DMC cities throughout Asia and

3
the Pacific and sector specialists from ADB and other development partners working on urban 
development projects.  
 
11.  To maximize the range of experience contributing to the TA, participating cities will be 
selected in consultation with regional department and resident mission staff and development 
partners, using criteria to ensure diversity in terms of regional representation, city size and type, 
risk profile, and level of capacity. Five to six cities will be involved in the workshop activities 
under the TA. These cities and DMCs have not been selected yet, but will be chosen on the 
basis of  
 
(i)  risk exposure and vulnerability, 
(ii)  regional/geographic diversity, 
(iii)  progress in initiating or achieving risk-sensitive land use plans and development 
projects, 
(iv)  alignment with country partnership strategies or country operation business plans, 
(v)  receptiveness to proposed TA outputs, 
(vi)  presence or absence of international donor community resources, and 
(vii)  potential to benefit cities through application of TA results to existing or future 
ADB investment projects (based on a review of ADB project pipelines for DMCs 
in which short-listed cities are located). 
 
12.  Three of the participating cities will also be selected for further development of case 
studies under the TA based on their experience in designing and implementing incentives for 
risk-sensitive land use management. 
 
13.  The TA will have three primary outputs: (i) development of guide and sector notes for 
integrating  risk-sensitive  land  use  management  into  sector  development  projects,  including 
urban development, transport, and water; (ii) case studies of incentives for DRR and CCA and 
how these have been used to align decision-making among various sets of urban stakeholders; 
and (iii) development of a set of urban risk indicators to track progress in implementing urban 
risk reduction measures. 
 
14.  Guide and sector notes for integrating risk-sensitive land use management into 
development  projects.  This  guide  will  help  national  and  local  governments  ensure  that 
infrastructure and settlements are sited and constructed with appropriate sensitivity to existing 
risks from all relevant natural hazards, as well as new and uncertain risks due to climate change. 
A set of sector notes on urban DRM will also be developed. Both the guide and the sector notes 
will cover good practices in the design, advocacy (awareness raising), implementation, and 
enforcement of effective risk-sensitive land use management measures, focusing, in particular, 
on the application of these tools in real contexts. Planned topics for the sector notes include 
risk-sensitive urban redevelopment (including public infrastructure as well as private businesses 
and housing); transport planning; and water, wastewater, and drainage planning, and will build 
on work ADB has recently collaborated on (such as the study of Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City and 
Manila6). As the Environmental and Safeguards Division of ADB’s Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) is currently in the process of developing a set of sector 
adaptation notes, these sector notes on urban DRM will be integrated into those adaptation

15.  Case studies of incentives for implementing DRR and adaptation measures. These 
case studies will focus on identifying how incentives (such as title amnesties, zoning easements, 
property or transfer tax breaks, insurance discounts, and credit provision) have been used to 
raise awareness and align decision-making with respect to DRR and CCA among various sets 
of urban stakeholders, including national and local governments, the private sector, civil society, 
and the residents of both formal and informal settlements. The case studies will also seek to 
identify gaps in the current application of incentives and to identify innovative solutions for 
addressing those gaps. 
 
16.  Set of urban resilience indicators. Several efforts have been made between 2001 and 
2009 to develop a set of urban resilience indicators, including initiatives by the Universidad 
Nacional de Columbia in Manizales, Columbia, the Inter-American Development Bank and the 
Earthquakes and Megacities Initiative. These have tended to be complex efforts to cover a wide 
range  of  factors  and  have  relied  on  black-box  formulas  and  weightings.  In  practice,  such 
indicators have not been widely adopted because of their inherent complexity and the difficulties 
in adapting the indicators more generally due to their proprietary or black-box nature. This 
component of the TA will focus on building a simple set of open indicators that could be applied 
and improved as part of (i) the Hyogo Framework for Action (HFA) local government reporting 
process that the UN International Strategy for Disaster Reduction (UN ISDR) is currently testing 
and rolling out, and (ii) the Global City Indicators Facility. By embedding these indicators within 
these  other  ongoing  initiatives,  their  generation  and  use  can  be  streamlined  to  increase 
adoption in cities throughout Asia and the Pacific. 
 
17.  The dissemination strategy for the outputs will include (i) local dissemination among 
decision-makers and practitioners within the participating cities, (ii) national dissemination in 
those  DMCs  through  professional  associations  and  networks,  and  (iii)  regional  and  global 
dissemination through ADB knowledge-sharing mechanisms and through initiatives such as the 
UN ISDR Making Cities Resilient campaign.8 Dissemination options include a web-based toolkit, 
internal  ADB  announcements,  workshops,  presentations  at  external  conferences,  and 
collaboration with relevant development networks and professional associations to promote the 
tools and related training materials to be developed under the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The research and development TA is estimated to cost $700,000. ADB will provide 
$371,000 from TASF—IV and $329,000 from TASF—other sources on a grant basis from its 
Technical Assistance Special Fund. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The  proposed  TA  will  be  implemented  over  26  months.  ADB,  through  the  Public 
Management, Governance, and Participation Division within the RSDD, will be the executing 
agency. The Public Management, Governance, and Participation Division will manage the TA in

20.  The TA will utilize 22.5 person-months of consultancy inputs to be provided by six 
international  consultants  (16.5  person-months)  and  three  national  consultants  (6  person-
months). The consultants will be engaged through a firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Given the project’s importance, 
complexity, and impact the quality- and cost-based selection method, based on a quality-to-cost 
ratio of 80:20, and simplified technical proposals will be used. Disbursements under the TA will 
be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, 
as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. 
Activities  funded  by  this  TA  are  subject  to  formal  review  and  approval  of  the  relevant 
governments  and  ADB.  The  TA  is  expected  to  be  implemented  from  November  2011  to 
December 2013.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis for 
Addressing Disaster Risk through Improved Indicators and Land Use Management, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Summary 
 
1.  A  team  of  international  consultants  will  be  recruited  to  work  under  the  technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  Addressing  Disaster  Risk  Through  Improved  Indicators  and  Land  Use 
Management and to collaborate with and be guided by staff from the Regional and Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Acting under the 
primary direction of RSDD, the team of specialists will design and develop guidance on risk-
sensitive land use planning; incentives for promoting risk reduction investments by national and 
local  governments,  the  private  sector,  and  civil  society;  and  straightforward  indicators  for 
measuring progress in risk reduction and adaptation. The team will work interactively with 
selected cities to review innovative urban risk reduction practice in those cities and elsewhere, 
and to outline the content, format, and dissemination strategy necessary to make urban risk 
reduction guidance available and accessible to planners to support their daily work. This will 
necessarily involve frequent collaboration among consultants, representatives from developing 
member countries (DMCs) and cities, other development partners, and ADB staff. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented over 26 months beginning in November 2011. ADB’s Public 
Management, Governance, and Participation Division within RSDD will be the executing agency. 
 
3.  A consultant firm or firms will work under the direction of the project officer in RSDD and 
be responsible for project assessment, implementation, and execution in collaboration with the 
DMC  cities  selected  to  participate  in  the  project.  The  firm(s)  will  have  broad  specialist 
knowledge and experience in risk-sensitive land use planning, disaster risk management, and 
climate change adaptation (CCA) within the Asia and Pacific region. The technical consultants 
will also have, or have ready access to, specialist expertise in urban development: water, 
wastewater, and drainage planning; economic incentives for urban development; and indicators. 
A firm may subcontract certain components of this project, based on its core business and 
expertise.  In  that  event,  the  firm  should  have  sufficient  internal  resources  and  technical 
experience to manage subcontractor output and be responsible for its content. The firm(s) 
should  also  have  experience  working  with  the  public  sector  in  the  field  of  disaster  risk 
management  and,  preferably,  a  sound  working  knowledge  of  ADB  and  its  operations  and 
policies. 
 
B.  Consultants  (total  6  international  consultants,  16.5  person-months;  3  national 
  consultants, 6 person-months) 
 
4.  The team leader (international consultant, who will serve as one of the risk-sensitive land 
use planning specialists, described below) will have specific expertise and project management 
experience related to risk-sensitive land use planning and will 
(i)  ensure that the TA is efficient and effective; 
(ii)  have the authority to act on the firm’s behalf to achieve the TA’s objectives; 
(iii)  coordinate and communicate routinely with the project officer in RSDD; 
(iv)  engage in all aspects of the project’s development stages, training programs, 
workshops, and stakeholder consultations; 
(v)  be available to work in-country as needed by the project team; 
(vi)  oversee achievement of all milestone activities and be responsible for periodic 
and final project reports; and

Appendix 3  11 
(vii)  take responsibility for the TA’s completion and success. 
 
1.  Risk-Sensitive  Land  Use  Planning  Specialists  (2  international,  6  person-
months total) 
 
5.  The consultants will be responsible for designing and authoring a guide and training 
materials on risk-sensitive land use planning and will need specialist knowledge of this subject 
area within the Asia and Pacific region. In addition, a working knowledge of urban development 
and climate change adaptation will be important. One consultant will need to have specialized 
knowledge and expertise in seismic hazard risk reduction. The consultants will 
(i)  collaborate  with  RSDD  disaster  risk  management  and  CCA  staff  and  other 
technical  consultants  on  the  project’s  design  and  planning,  and  develop  an 
implementation and reporting schedule; 
(ii)  conduct a regional scoping to identify potential selected cities to engage; 
(iii)  organize a workshop to bring together teams from five to six selected cities to 
present good practices in their own cities and outline user and dissemination 
requirements for the guide and related materials; 
(iv)  meet  and  correspond  with  sector  development  specialists  at  ADB  and 
development partners to gather input for the guide and training materials; 
(v)  develop a detailed outline for guide on risk-sensitive land use planning based on 
the workshop and other feedback; 
(vi)  conduct follow-up visits to three cities to document specific practices within cities, 
develop requirements for materials, and provide feedback on content developed 
to date; 
(vii)  develop a draft of the guide and related training materials and test them with staff 
from participating cities and sector specialists at ADB and development partners; 
(viii)  provide guidance to consultants working on sector notes regarding conclusions 
on content, format, and dissemination strategy as a result of a workshop with 
cities and meetings with sector development specialists; 
(ix)  present and review the guide at a relevant regional conference for feedback; and 
(x)  finalize the guide and training materials. 
 
2.  Risk-Sensitive Land Use Planning Specialists (3 national, 6 person-months 
total) 
 
6.  The consultants will be responsible for conducting background research on risk-sensitive 
land use planning practice in the three cities selected for detailed case studies. Each of these 
consultants will need specialist knowledge of this subject area within one of the selected cities. 
In addition, a working knowledge of urban development and climate change adaptation will be 
important. The consultants will 
(i)  collaborate with the team leader and other technical consultants on the design, 
planning,  and  development  of  city  case  studies  on  risk-sensitive  land  use 
planning;  
(ii)  conduct background research and interviews with a range of city stakeholders

and civil society) to document specific practices within the selected cities;

(iii)  collaborate with the team leader and other technical consultants in analyzing 
research  and  interview  results  to  develop  draft  case  study  overviews  to  be 
included in the guide and related training materials; 
(iv)  collaborate with the team leader and other technical consultants to test draft case 
study materials with staff from participating cities and local development partners; 
and 
(v)  provide guidance to consultants working on sector notes regarding conclusions 
on content, format, and dissemination strategy as a result of a workshop with 
cities and meetings with sector development specialists. 
 
3.  Urban Development Specialist (1 international, 2 person-months) 
 
7.  The consultant will be responsible for designing and authoring a 20-page sector note on 
integrating risk-sensitive land use planning into urban redevelopment projects.1 The note should 
draw on insights and learning from good practice in urban redevelopment related to reducing 
exposure and vulnerability to hazards and strengthening community resilience. The consultant 
will need specialist knowledge of urban redevelopment within the Asia and Pacific region. In 
addition, a working knowledge of and experience in disaster risk management and climate 
change adaptation under an all-hazards approach will be important. The consultant will 
(i)  collaborate  with  RSDD  disaster  risk  management  and  CCA  staff  and  other 
technical  consultants  on  the  project’s  design  and  planning  and  develop  an 
implementation and reporting schedule; 
(ii)  conduct a regional scoping to identify good practices in integrating risk-sensitive 
land use planning into urban redevelopment projects; 
(iii)  assist in conducting a workshop with selected cities to gather input for the urban 
redevelopment sector note; 
(iv)  meet  and  correspond  with  sector  development  specialists  at  ADB  and 
development partners to gather input for the sector note; 
(v)  develop a draft of the sector note to review with staff from participating cities and 
sector specialists at ADB and development partners; and 
(vi)  finalize the sector note based on input and feedback from staff of participating 
cities, sector specialists at ADB, and development partners. 
 
4.  Water,  Wastewater,  and  Drainage  Planning  Specialist  (1  international,  2 
person-months) 
 
8.  The  consultant  will  be  responsible  for  designing  and  authoring  a  sector  note  on 
integrating risk-sensitive land use planning into water, wastewater, and drainage projects. The 
note should draw on insights and learning from good practice in the water sector regarding the 
effective  integration  of  flood  risk  management  into  water  sector  projects,  as  well  as  the 
protection of those projects and communities’ access to their services from all types of disaster 
risk  that  may  be  present.  The  consultant  will  need  specialist  knowledge  of  water-related 
development projects within the Asia and Pacific region. In addition, a working knowledge of

5.  Incentives for Risk Reduction and Adaptation Specialist (1 international, 3 
person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant will be responsible for developing an analytic study of incentives for risk 
reduction and adaptation in the urban development context. The consultant will need specialist 
knowledge of development economics within the Asia and Pacific region. In addition, a working 
knowledge of disaster risk management and climate change adaptation will be important. The 
consultant will 
(i)  collaborate  with  RSDD  disaster  risk  management  and  CCA  staff  and  other 
technical  consultants  on  the  project’s  design  and  planning,  and  develop  an 
implementation and reporting schedule; 
(ii)  conduct a regional scoping and desk review to identify existing experience with 
incentives for risk reduction and adaptation; 
(iii)  assist in conducting a workshop with selected cities to review their experience 
with incentives and identify requirements for planned guidance on incentives; 
(iv)  meet  and  correspond  with  sector  development  specialists  at  ADB  and 
development partners to gather input for the incentives study; 
(v)  conduct site visits to review and document key incentives examples; 
(vi)  develop a set of case studies for good practice examples and revise based on 
input and feedback from staff of participating cities, sector specialists at ADB, 
and development partners; and 
(vii)  develop  recommendations  for  further  ADB  follow-up  on  incentives  for  risk 
reduction and adaptation.
